DaFlipp's Ameteur Gamer's Guide to Nagas
Monster Rancher Metropolis: Monster Rancher 2 Archive (PSOne): Monster Types: Naga: DaFlipp's Ameteur Gamer's Guide to Nagas
By DaFlipp on Sunday, July 23, 2000 - 11:08 am:

Okay, so I raised, ummm... one Naga. And, uhh... I did poorly at it. Well, this topic is lonely, okay?!

Actually, I raised TWO nagas. The first one I got most of my info from, a Striker (Naga/Tiger). Let me say this - Nagas are one of the COOLEST-looking breeds in the game! Okay, said it. Now...

Nagas have a lot of potential. I say this because of Susvain. Susvain was always my nemesis for... what is he, B Rank? C rank? Whichever, he's a Naga/Zuum whose stats were usually all higher or close to whatever I had except for intelligence. (When I got my Golems going, their Power usually beat out Susvain's, but other than that, they usually beat most of their stats). Nagas are terribly well-rounded, it seems. Their only weakness is low Intelligence, but that doesn't come into play much - their Int attacks are usually just used for Withering, and if you have a good sub-breed, like Tiger (hehe), you'll thwomp 'em in no time.

Power and Skill are their best stats, I think. Power is very important because, without it, you'll have a hard time beating monsters. It's wonderful to have a high-skill monster, which I'm starting to miss after those Golems and Durahans. Sure, there are freak accidents (How the &^%#*@^$*$&@$ did Rockgeiger dodge three Stabs in a row?!?!), but overall, they work well. They're NOT one-hit-wonders, and I wouldn't count on Speed Demon or Tank (although sub-breeds would help with either), but they are good at... ummm... well, I always used Desperation, but I think Combo King would work better, now that I think about it. I think the guts regen was about average, and the attacks tended to be quick, low damage attacks rather than drawn-out pummeling attacks.

As for life on the farm... well, I imagine most breeds would be living hell to raise. The Tiger sub-breed helped out a LOT, and I got a friendly creature with Best nature who was actually funny to watch (have you seen their happy dance? HA HA HA!!!). Train power and skill primarily, then either speed or defense depending on the sub-breed. Only train intelligence if you have an agreeable sub.

Oh, and the other Naga I trained? Well, Nagas have short lifespans. I wanted to get a Mock without "wasting" a monster. I had a Purple Suezo on a disc that I combined with something, and I lucked out and got a pure Naga. I was horrible to him. He was full-grown in a few months, with the amount of lifespan I was shaving off of him. I think that was the first time I ever saw "Truancy".

I was re-introduced to the power of a Naga's gains. I mainly put him through the Power Errantry and Endure drills (Endure because it looks the most painful, plus Swim drills occaisonally). I put him in a tournament to have KO's shave more life off of him. He won them. Whoa.

Consider this a sample review before Nate gets around to reviewing these. Y'know, and does a GOOD job of it?

Man, I'm bored.... Ciao.

By Rob Isaacson on Thursday, February 8, 2001 - 12:34 pm:

Freak accidents, my butt! I'm convinced that Rockgieger has a *much* higher SPD than the 25 or so the game claims he has. Against monsters with SKI in the 200-300 range, he dodges roughly 3 times out of any 4 given attacks!!

Maybe a little hint from our friends at Tecmo not to take everything you read at face value..?

How do you guys keep the Nagas out of Fond?? I do exactly like I do with every other monster, and when I do FINALLY get a naga out of Fond, I'll rest them on the week their due or do weight maintence(sp?) and the next thing I know, I'm back at Fond! If this will help, I usually do three light and a rest during their baby to childhood until I get to prime and then switch to 4th week HD food 1st week LD 2nd week NO and HD and 3rd week ML and rest... what am I doing wrong with these bipedal snakes?
